 The January number for 1897, will be en- beIIished with portrait of the late venerable JOHN ADAMS, formerly President of the United States, one of LoDgacre's best engra- wings also, a correct and beautiful view of FAIR MOUNT WATER WORKS, in the vicinity of Philadelphia besides, the first No. of the SCHOOL OF FLORA, being the commencement of q regcar series of Treati- ses on Botany, illustrated with numererous cuts. ..r

 Post-masters and publishers of papers who will interest themselves in obtaining subscri- bers, and be responsible for the subscription, shall be entitled to every sixth copy gratis. Address.

 ATKINSON & ALEX NpER, Philadelphia.

 Persons wishing to subscribe, will please to send in their names by the first of the year, as there is no doubt the demand for the work will be greatly increased, and therefose the possibility of being furnished with the Nos. from the beginning, will be rendered more doubtful. 29

To induce the numerous correspondents of the Saturday Evening Post and others to fur nisL original essays and metrical compositions particularly calculated to enrich the columns of the Casket for 1927, the publishers have been induced to offer the following rewards:

 l. The Caskct for 1926, 1927 and 1895, embellished with numerovs engravings, and handsomely bound in rich extra bindings, for the best Essay, in prose, of moderate length

 9. The Casket for three years commen- cing with the volume just finished bound ill the same superb manner, for the JrSt American Tale, of moderate length

 3. The Casket for three years, commencing as above, bound in a superb style, for the best Biography of Anne, ican character, male and female,

 4. The Casket for three years, or five years Subscription of the Saturday Evening Post, for the best netrcal composition not exceed ing sixty lines.

 One years subscription to the Casket for 1927 will be awarded to each of the second best articles in either of the above depart ments.

 The articles must be addressed to Atkinson g. Aleranaer, Philadelphia {post paid) and han ded in by the first of March next, when they will undergo the inspection of three Literary gentlemen ofthis city, and the awerds be dis tribnted with fairness and npartiaiity.

 Editors throughout the Uuion friendly to American Literature will piepsc to give this notice two or thre insertions.
PR E TELUNE $.

l OFFICE OF THE SATURDAY EVENING PosT, Philadelphia, Dec. 9, 1926. THE CASKET, or FIo,cers of Literature, 1 Fit anu Sentiment, which has had an uupre- | cedented increase of patrons during the last six months, will, after the present volume is finished, contain, each number, forty octave pages, printed well, on small handsome type, upon the finest paper, stitched and covered. and furnished to subscribers at the ioN price of Two Dollars and fifty cents per annum. The Casket is collection from the choicest pieces of the Saturday Evening Post, made with reference to the difference which should exist in the materials Ofa weekly pa per, and those of d monthly publication, the former of course enriched with essays. poetry, anecdotes, and those set off by recital ofthe occurrences of the week. The latter can re- ceiye little value from mere detall of events, many of which would cease to be interesting before they were recorded.

 The vast quantity of matter crowded, by small type, and careful arrangement into the columns of every number of the Saturday Evening Post, will in the course of month, to form an interesting and periodical N ork such as the Casket has been considered by its partial friends, and such as we intend, it shaN Dc. Notwithstanding the fact, that the Cask- ct is hut collection from the Saturday Eve hing Post, we confidently predict, and indeed we are sanctioned in the experience we alrea- dy have, that its most numerous patrons will be found among the subscribers to our weekly papcr.-A large number of those who take the :. Post'' depend upon that paper for the news of the week-it is therefore read with avidity by almost every member of the family where it is received, and this general use frequently iniuresits appearance so much as almost to render it unfit for the file, and for binding. The numbers too, by this general use, are not un- frequently lost, mutulated or entirely destroy ed, and the file thus brOken.-The Casket is calculated to prevent this inconvenience, and to furnish, at a very cheap price, all the useful matter for which the weekly paper would be desirable when bound.-In thus giving per manent form and select association to the choice pieces of our weekly contributors, it is confidently anticipated that new and success full inducements will be held out for the exer- else of superior talent, and unusual care m our literary department.-In addition to the recommendation of aeatness in the generalap-' pearance-and particular attention to the ty- geographical execution, it is our intention to embellish each number of the |" "Casket" with three handsome Engravings from the hands of some of the most distinguished artists of the country. ....

 With these claims to patronage, the :: Gas ket'' will, as has been previously mentioned, be afforded to those who subscribe for thdt paper exclusively, at the low price of Ss,50

largement, Or a respite from our galling Op precision. Besides all thss, it was unqUestiOna- bly owing in a chief degree to the repeated eloquence, and fOrcible appeals of Mrs. Jud- son. that the untutored Birman was finally made willing tO secure the welfare and happi- ness of his country by sincere peace."

 Ledther and PruHeiIa.-A writer in the Mer- rimack Journal has opened a battery against the fashion of wearing cloth shoes by the la dies. He says, with good justice: .

 "If there is any one constant practice that deserves execratiOn, this is it. Examine the many cases of consumption and decline now prevalent throughout our country and it will be found that first of all, the patient byscloth shoes got her feet wet which caused slight cold-before the first cold was fairly cured a second one was taken by the same careless ness and so it continues until a consumption is seated-whGn after lingering few months death ends the scene. It fact which pre- sume will not be disputed, that twenty females at least are carried out of the world by con- sumption where one male is. l believe this cannot be accounted for in any other manner than that men are not tenth part so careless of their health as ladies are. You can scarcely name prudent man who will consent to have his feet wet by thin shoes, two or three times a week; on the contrary many take a meth ed to have their boots water proof. If the la- dies think that lasting, or valentia or satin shoes are handsomer than those made of kid or leather, they are sadly mistaken, at least in the opinion of the gentlemen

COLLECTORS NOTICE.

se,.u,;rn in heaven. On this event were pro- mulrated those "glad tidings of great joy" by an angel, to the shepherds of Bethlehem, and which were soon to be published to all peopIe. ."-And we read, that suddenly there was with the angel multitude of the heav- enly host praising God, and saying, Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good will toward men,"

 Oh! what an interchangeable an auspi- cious day to our benighted world, and to heaven! Types, and shadows, and sacrifices, were now sealed up in the great Antitype,- the I |" nite Sacrifice for dying man. A ret respect of almost eighteen centuries, will place us upon that page of times when the Saviour closed his mission, and purchased our redemption by his death on the cross /! There we may read in luminous characters, which eternity will never expunge, that SaIVdttOn 65 1 Christ is proclaimed as the only remedy for the maIadies of an apostate world. All the hopes and blessings of eternal life, rebound to man through the medium of that Cross !-All the divine decrees from etcrnity,-the costly sacrifices that have bled upon ten thousand alters, and the rivers which have flowed as sacred libations, and all the prophecies of old centre here, exhibiting the divine pertections in blaze of inaffable glory, lifting that veil of mystery whence hope springs forth on sinful, dying world. .---

 PAMELA.

 December, 35, 1928.

NOTICE.

From the Atbany Argus.

 A SKETCH.

 '" IHe only green leafo her heart has aOithered''

 It was a night of beauty ;-The moon was riding high in Heaven, and seemed to look with watchful eyes on all the slumbering in- habitants of the world she brightned. No. thing disturbed the Loneliness of the Widows chamber, save the sweet notes of the nightin- gale at intervals, and the low c0oings of the dove. The playful breeze brought on its loaded wing the perfume ofmany sweets,and the combined fragrance of the rose and the jasmine seemed in gratitude toshover around her who had raised them into beauty, and to ask why she did not smile as she was wont to do, and come and cherish them. But the lonely widow thought not of the flowers she. loved andghad nursed so tenderly. She saw not the brilliant moon, dancing throug Aeecy clouds, and then spreading abroad it's beams unobscured. She heard not the sweet bird of evening or if she did, his sweet warblng grated harshly over her souE The complain ing note of the tender dove was all that har monized with her feelings tsoothed hertroub- led spirit without even the consciousness that she heard it That anxious mother wait ed sons return. Often had she sat hours watching for him, but tonight never before had he fingered so late, and the mother fear fully awaited the cause. She sat cOmmun- ing with her God, and endeavoring to draw from that sacred source, array of hope or con- solation. Whose feverish tread is that "Tis his !-and anxiously the widow raised the latch to look in her sons face. She did look for one moment, ,On the face once bright with smiles and the contentment of plous heart How was it changed since that once happy time! Now in feverish and brilliant excite ment it burned in radiant beauty. The motA- CT seated herselfinresigned agony. How was her beautiful boy, the pride of her years, al tered Now twas almost a raving maniac that stood as horribly erect before her.

 "Yes, I'll tell you all, mother I'll tell you how your son was damned. l was wild with cursed wine when did the hellish deed- but Pm cool now. Oh yes I'm cool noio ~ and he pressed his burning brow. "Moth- CT !'' and he spoke less wildly, ..give me your blessing 'tis my last boon:'' and he fell at her feet and threw his arms around her. The widow laid her hands on the boys head-"Harry know not what you intend, or what great crime you have committed, but oh, my son ! mothers blessing rest upon you, and her prayers be with you, whether guilty or inocent."

 The young man sprang from his knees, pressed long kiss on those hallowed lips he had edby his wiekedness -and !. fed

 Next morning there was search made for "Harry Wilson, the young .torger.-He was found drowned in the pond at the foot of his mothers garden. For the widows sake,none of the sad particulars of his crime or of his fate were noised abrUad hut all unearthly kindness was soon uunecessary--The wid owed mothers soul had reached its final glo rious home. ZAlE.

 An American Lady.-The following article from the Calcutta Government Gazette, gives some interesting particulars respecting the ve- ry praise worthy and useful services of Mrs. Judson :.-

 ''In printing my last communication there was a trinng mistake made: it should have been Mrs. not Mir. as that lady was the au- thor ofthose eloquent and forcible appeals to the Government which prepaired item by de- grees for submission of terms of peace, never expected by any who knew the hauteur, and |sinAexible pride of the Birman Court and while on this subject, the overAowings of grateful feelings, on behalf of myself and fel- low prisoners, compel me to add tribute of public thanks to that amable and humane female, who, though living at the distance of two miles from our prison without any means ofconveyance, and very feeble in health, for got her own comfort and infrmity ,and almost every day visited us, sought out and admins tered to our wants, and contributed, in every way to alleviate the burthcn of our misery. While we were all left, by the Government destitute of food, she, with an unweried per severance, obtained for us, by some means or other, constant supply. When the tattered state of our cloths evinced the extremity of our distress, she was ever ready to replenish Iour scanty wardrobe. When the unfeeling avarice of our keepers confined us insde or made our feet fast in stocks, she like minis tering angel, never ceased her applications to the Government. until she was authorised to ! communicate to us the grateful news of en-
PAMELA.
December, 95, 1928.

Birth, again greets tle Cnflstian world. It comes to remind us of that glorious era, when the Son of God appeared ih our world to re- deem his pledge, agreeably to the contract of his Father in the eternal councils of heaven |: Ut comes to remind us of that sacred day.

 when the Babe of Bethlehem appeared, and

 halowed it by his advent, ana his assumption

 of our nature :-It comes to remind us of that event. when the great, and sublime scene of

 Redemption was disclosed to ruined and re-

 volting world ;-and it comes to remind us of

 the development of that stupendous scheme

 of Mercy, which projected by the adorable

 Trinity in heaven, for the restoration of i'm

 mortal beings, aud to display to intelligences the wisdom, and power and glory of the Fri

 une God!

 s Were we to trace the grand line of history, down the long lapse of time from the crea-

 ton to this era, our world would present Ilt- :. He else. than one continued scene of conten-

 ton, war, and blood Kingdoms, nations S

 empires had arisen, fourished, and passed a.

 way in oblivion. The rock of power-the

 adamant of genius-the monumental troph-

 ies of ancient art and glory had crumbIed in-

 to ruins ;-and in vain were it to enquire for the vast and gigantic thrones of antiquity ;- the temple of the sun-the hoary oracles of former ages-the lofty arehes-the splendid

 palaces, and the mighty towers of imperial

 Babylon,-the harlot of the world. Needless

 were it to look for those renowned nations once studded with the stars of empire-those rich and splendid navies, with the gold of O. phir-the cedar and the lofty fir of Lebanon

 -the olive and the palm of Idumea-the pu- merous nations marshalling to arms,-the rushing of chariots-the bleeding of millions, and the hecatombs of human victims blazing upon the accursed altars AlSs! They had passed away in the raging storm, and the sweeping tempest had hurnbIe1. them in the dust (which the oblivious pail has suspend ed over them, and the mournful voice of his- tory proclaimed only that they had been The principal nations of the earth being now re- duced under one head, and wars and commO- lions revolving through long tracts of time, now terminating in one immense dominion, the troubled and coDtending elements of hu- man society sunk into an universal calm, or were hushed to repose by the advent of the Prince of Peace!

 gNhiu info ovnnf tnaL VNln hn1,f 0n0n years after God promised to Abraham, that in his seed all the nations of the earth should be blessed. This glorious promise had never been, but partially verified in anticedent events but now, after the lapse of two millenares, the Son of God appeared in our world, and by his life and doctrines, his death and resu- rection, fulfilled the predictions--dispeled the shadows of the Mosaic dispensation, and O. pened the way for the promugation of the Gospel throughout the world. Patriarchs & prophets, and the wise in every period, look ed through the vista of ages with the eye of aith, and beheId with the most pleasing an- icipations the dawnings of this suspicious day o the posterity of man.-H was proclaimed Q them by the Most High ;--it was register d in the Jewish canon, and was the bright & morning Star of that legacy, and could he raced by them through all the sacred wri- Eings. It is there only that Shiloh so early promised, speaks down through succession of types and shadows, till the great Antitype appears in the manager at Bethlehem! M

 On this day, through the long visitation of more than 1900 years, we can look back to that halcyon morning, over which the lapse of ages has thrown no obscurity, and contem- plate him feeble, helpless infant, commen- cing life of sorrow, and affiiction, and per secution,-but of one continued series of acts ofhenevolence and mercy. On this day, Christ commenced that career of life, which closed on the Cross of Calvery for the redemption of bis enemies :--or as the prophet feelingly, and forcibly expresses it. "He was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our in- iquities; the reinstatement of our peace was upon him, and by his stripes we are healed." Let us then when this day rolls her annual round, and while we are pilgrims here below, looking forward with hope to enjoy that rest, and fhneO ivnnkrsS hal hla iponunifiaS havond

 l. The Caskct for 1926, 1927 and 1895, embellished with numerovs engravings, and handsomely bound in rich extra bindings, for the best Essay, in prose, of moderate length

 9. The Casket for three years commen- cing with the volume just finished bound ill the same superb manner, for the JrSt American Tale, of moderate length

 3. The Casket for three years, commencing as above, bound in a superb style, for the best Biography of Anne, ican character, male and female,

 4. The Casket for three years, or five years Subscription of the Saturday Evening Post, for the best netrcal composition not exceed ing sixty lines.

 One years subscription to the Casket for 1927 will be awarded to each of the second best articles in either of the above depart ments.

THE CASKET,

 OR FLOWERS OF LITERATURE, WIT & SENTIMENT. FOR 1927,
full articles.article:
l OFFICE OF THE SATURDAY EVENING PosT, Philadelphia, Dec. 9, 1926. THE CASKET, or FIo,cers of Literature, 1 Fit anu Sentiment, which has had an uupre- | cedented increase of patrons during the last six months, will, after the present volume is finished, contain, each number, forty octave pages, printed well, on small handsome type, upon the finest paper, stitched and covered. and furnished to subscribers at the ioN price of Two Dollars and fifty cents per annum. The Casket is collection from the choicest pieces of the Saturday Evening Post, made with reference to the difference which should exist in the materials Ofa weekly pa per, and those of d monthly publication, the former of course enriched with essays. poetry, anecdotes, and those set off by recital ofthe occurrences of the week. The latter can re- ceiye little value from mere detall of events, many of which would cease to be interesting before they were recorded.

 The vast quantity of matter crowded, by small type, and careful arrangement into the columns of every number of the Saturday Evening Post, will in the course of month, to form an interesting and periodical N ork such as the Casket has been considered by its partial friends, and such as we intend, it shaN Dc. Notwithstanding the fact, that the Cask- ct is hut collection from the Saturday Eve hing Post, we confidently predict, and indeed we are sanctioned in the experience we alrea- dy have, that its most numerous patrons will be found among the subscribers to our weekly papcr.-A large number of those who take the :. Post'' depend upon that paper for the news of the week-it is therefore read with avidity by almost every member of the family where it is received, and this general use frequently iniuresits appearance so much as almost to render it unfit for the file, and for binding. The numbers too, by this general use, are not un- frequently lost, mutulated or entirely destroy ed, and the file thus brOken.-The Casket is calculated to prevent this inconvenience, and to furnish, at a very cheap price, all the useful matter for which the weekly paper would be desirable when bound.-In thus giving per manent form and select association to the choice pieces of our weekly contributors, it is confidently anticipated that new and success full inducements will be held out for the exer- else of superior talent, and unusual care m our literary department.-In addition to the recommendation of aeatness in the generalap-' pearance-and particular attention to the ty- geographical execution, it is our intention to embellish each number of the |" "Casket" with three handsome Engravings from the hands of some of the most distinguished artists of the country. ....

 With these claims to patronage, the :: Gas ket'' will, as has been previously mentioned, be afforded to those who subscribe for thdt paper exclusively, at the low price of Ss,50

largement, Or a respite from our galling Op precision. Besides all thss, it was unqUestiOna- bly owing in a chief degree to the repeated eloquence, and fOrcible appeals of Mrs. Jud- son. that the untutored Birman was finally made willing tO secure the welfare and happi- ness of his country by sincere peace."

 Ledther and PruHeiIa.-A writer in the Mer- rimack Journal has opened a battery against the fashion of wearing cloth shoes by the la dies. He says, with good justice: .

 "If there is any one constant practice that deserves execratiOn, this is it. Examine the many cases of consumption and decline now prevalent throughout our country and it will be found that first of all, the patient byscloth shoes got her feet wet which caused slight cold-before the first cold was fairly cured a second one was taken by the same careless ness and so it continues until a consumption is seated-whGn after lingering few months death ends the scene. It fact which pre- sume will not be disputed, that twenty females at least are carried out of the world by con- sumption where one male is. l believe this cannot be accounted for in any other manner than that men are not tenth part so careless of their health as ladies are. You can scarcely name prudent man who will consent to have his feet wet by thin shoes, two or three times a week; on the contrary many take a meth ed to have their boots water proof. If the la- dies think that lasting, or valentia or satin shoes are handsomer than those made of kid or leather, they are sadly mistaken, at least in the opinion of the gentlemen

full articles.article:
.EIHE residents and presidents of the

 1 town of Kent who are liable by law to pay taxes, are hereby notified that the sub scriber has received warrant to collect a town tax of them laid on the List of 1895, & will meet them at the Inn of Philo Mills on the first Monday of February, 1927 at the Inn of John w. McKoy on the second Mon day of February, 1927; and at the Inn of Wm. T. HOpson on the third Monday of Feb ruary, 1927, in said Kent, at each of said pla- ces at nine o'clock A. M. to receive said tax es. All those who neglect to pay at said dates must expect to pay the travelling fees allowed by law.

 HIRAM CONVERSE, Collector.

 Kent, Dec. @5, 1926. 29

se,.u,;rn in heaven. On this event were pro- mulrated those "glad tidings of great joy" by an angel, to the shepherds of Bethlehem, and which were soon to be published to all peopIe. ."-And we read, that suddenly there was with the angel multitude of the heav- enly host praising God, and saying, Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good will toward men,"

 Oh! what an interchangeable an auspi- cious day to our benighted world, and to heaven! Types, and shadows, and sacrifices, were now sealed up in the great Antitype,- the I |" nite Sacrifice for dying man. A ret respect of almost eighteen centuries, will place us upon that page of times when the Saviour closed his mission, and purchased our redemption by his death on the cross /! There we may read in luminous characters, which eternity will never expunge, that SaIVdttOn 65 1 Christ is proclaimed as the only remedy for the maIadies of an apostate world. All the hopes and blessings of eternal life, rebound to man through the medium of that Cross !-All the divine decrees from etcrnity,-the costly sacrifices that have bled upon ten thousand alters, and the rivers which have flowed as sacred libations, and all the prophecies of old centre here, exhibiting the divine pertections in blaze of inaffable glory, lifting that veil of mystery whence hope springs forth on sinful, dying world. .---

 PAMELA.

 December, 35, 1928.

full articles.headline:
PAMELA.

December, 95, 1928.
full articles.article:
From the Atbany Argus.

 A SKETCH.

 '" IHe only green leafo her heart has aOithered''

 It was a night of beauty ;-The moon was riding high in Heaven, and seemed to look with watchful eyes on all the slumbering in- habitants of the world she brightned. No. thing disturbed the Loneliness of the Widows chamber, save the sweet notes of the nightin- gale at intervals, and the low c0oings of the dove. The playful breeze brought on its loaded wing the perfume ofmany sweets,and the combined fragrance of the rose and the jasmine seemed in gratitude toshover around her who had raised them into beauty, and to ask why she did not smile as she was wont to do, and come and cherish them. But the lonely widow thought not of the flowers she. loved andghad nursed so tenderly. She saw not the brilliant moon, dancing throug Aeecy clouds, and then spreading abroad it's beams unobscured. She heard not the sweet bird of evening or if she did, his sweet warblng grated harshly over her souE The complain ing note of the tender dove was all that har monized with her feelings tsoothed hertroub- led spirit without even the consciousness that she heard it That anxious mother wait ed sons return. Often had she sat hours watching for him, but tonight never before had he fingered so late, and the mother fear fully awaited the cause. She sat cOmmun- ing with her God, and endeavoring to draw from that sacred source, array of hope or con- solation. Whose feverish tread is that "Tis his !-and anxiously the widow raised the latch to look in her sons face. She did look for one moment, ,On the face once bright with smiles and the contentment of plous heart How was it changed since that once happy time! Now in feverish and brilliant excite ment it burned in radiant beauty. The motA- CT seated herselfinresigned agony. How was her beautiful boy, the pride of her years, al tered Now twas almost a raving maniac that stood as horribly erect before her.

 "Yes, I'll tell you all, mother I'll tell you how your son was damned. l was wild with cursed wine when did the hellish deed- but Pm cool now. Oh yes I'm cool noio ~ and he pressed his burning brow. "Moth- CT !'' and he spoke less wildly, ..give me your blessing 'tis my last boon:'' and he fell at her feet and threw his arms around her. The widow laid her hands on the boys head-"Harry know not what you intend, or what great crime you have committed, but oh, my son ! mothers blessing rest upon you, and her prayers be with you, whether guilty or inocent."

 The young man sprang from his knees, pressed long kiss on those hallowed lips he had edby his wiekedness -and !. fed

 Next morning there was search made for "Harry Wilson, the young .torger.-He was found drowned in the pond at the foot of his mothers garden. For the widows sake,none of the sad particulars of his crime or of his fate were noised abrUad hut all unearthly kindness was soon uunecessary--The wid owed mothers soul had reached its final glo rious home. ZAlE.

 An American Lady.-The following article from the Calcutta Government Gazette, gives some interesting particulars respecting the ve- ry praise worthy and useful services of Mrs. Judson :.-

 ''In printing my last communication there was a trinng mistake made: it should have been Mrs. not Mir. as that lady was the au- thor ofthose eloquent and forcible appeals to the Government which prepaired item by de- grees for submission of terms of peace, never expected by any who knew the hauteur, and |sinAexible pride of the Birman Court and while on this subject, the overAowings of grateful feelings, on behalf of myself and fel- low prisoners, compel me to add tribute of public thanks to that amable and humane female, who, though living at the distance of two miles from our prison without any means ofconveyance, and very feeble in health, for got her own comfort and infrmity ,and almost every day visited us, sought out and admins tered to our wants, and contributed, in every way to alleviate the burthcn of our misery. While we were all left, by the Government destitute of food, she, with an unweried per severance, obtained for us, by some means or other, constant supply. When the tattered state of our cloths evinced the extremity of our distress, she was ever ready to replenish Iour scanty wardrobe. When the unfeeling avarice of our keepers confined us insde or made our feet fast in stocks, she like minis tering angel, never ceased her applications to the Government. until she was authorised to ! communicate to us the grateful news of en-

full articles.headline: FoR gxE c0UHwv POST. CHRISTMAS.
full articles.article:
Birth, again greets tle Cnflstian world. It comes to remind us of that glorious era, when the Son of God appeared ih our world to re- deem his pledge, agreeably to the contract of his Father in the eternal councils of heaven |: Ut comes to remind us of that sacred day.

 when the Babe of Bethlehem appeared, and

 halowed it by his advent, ana his assumption

 of our nature :-It comes to remind us of that event. when the great, and sublime scene of

 Redemption was disclosed to ruined and re-

 volting world ;-and it comes to remind us of

 the development of that stupendous scheme

 of Mercy, which projected by the adorable

 Trinity in heaven, for the restoration of i'm

 mortal beings, aud to display to intelligences the wisdom, and power and glory of the Fri

 une God!

 s Were we to trace the grand line of history, down the long lapse of time from the crea-

 ton to this era, our world would present Ilt- :. He else. than one continued scene of conten-

 ton, war, and blood Kingdoms, nations S

 empires had arisen, fourished, and passed a.

 way in oblivion. The rock of power-the

 adamant of genius-the monumental troph-

 ies of ancient art and glory had crumbIed in-

 to ruins ;-and in vain were it to enquire for the vast and gigantic thrones of antiquity ;- the temple of the sun-the hoary oracles of former ages-the lofty arehes-the splendid

 palaces, and the mighty towers of imperial

 Babylon,-the harlot of the world. Needless

 were it to look for those renowned nations once studded with the stars of empire-those rich and splendid navies, with the gold of O. phir-the cedar and the lofty fir of Lebanon

 -the olive and the palm of Idumea-the pu- merous nations marshalling to arms,-the rushing of chariots-the bleeding of millions, and the hecatombs of human victims blazing upon the accursed altars AlSs! They had passed away in the raging storm, and the sweeping tempest had hurnbIe1. them in the dust (which the oblivious pail has suspend ed over them, and the mournful voice of his- tory proclaimed only that they had been The principal nations of the earth being now re- duced under one head, and wars and commO- lions revolving through long tracts of time, now terminating in one immense dominion, the troubled and coDtending elements of hu- man society sunk into an universal calm, or were hushed to repose by the advent of the Prince of Peace!

 gNhiu info ovnnf tnaL VNln hn1,f 0n0n years after God promised to Abraham, that in his seed all the nations of the earth should be blessed. This glorious promise had never been, but partially verified in anticedent events but now, after the lapse of two millenares, the Son of God appeared in our world, and by his life and doctrines, his death and resu- rection, fulfilled the predictions--dispeled the shadows of the Mosaic dispensation, and O. pened the way for the promugation of the Gospel throughout the world. Patriarchs & prophets, and the wise in every period, look ed through the vista of ages with the eye of aith, and beheId with the most pleasing an- icipations the dawnings of this suspicious day o the posterity of man.-H was proclaimed Q them by the Most High ;--it was register d in the Jewish canon, and was the bright & morning Star of that legacy, and could he raced by them through all the sacred wri- Eings. It is there only that Shiloh so early promised, speaks down through succession of types and shadows, till the great Antitype appears in the manager at Bethlehem! M

 On this day, through the long visitation of more than 1900 years, we can look back to that halcyon morning, over which the lapse of ages has thrown no obscurity, and contem- plate him feeble, helpless infant, commen- cing life of sorrow, and affiiction, and per secution,-but of one continued series of acts ofhenevolence and mercy. On this day, Christ commenced that career of life, which closed on the Cross of Calvery for the redemption of bis enemies :--or as the prophet feelingly, and forcibly expresses it. "He was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our in- iquities; the reinstatement of our peace was upon him, and by his stripes we are healed." Let us then when this day rolls her annual round, and while we are pilgrims here below, looking forward with hope to enjoy that rest, and fhneO ivnnkrsS hal hla iponunifiaS havond

situated in the townshis of Orwell, Warren & Windham, in the County of Bradford, Penn sylvana, about 145 miles west of Newburg, 28 west of Montrose the seat of Justice of Susquehanna county Pa. A from Towanda, the courty site of Bradford county; and l6 south of Owego, in the state of New York, and 10 miles east of the Susquehanna river Said Lands to be surveyed into lots to suit purchasers at the expense of the owncr; at the low rate of S1 50 per Acre, Cash or S9,5O m credit of four years, The subscriber hay ing resided on this tract land for some years, can recommend the quality of the soil to be equal if not superior to any tract of land in the country for Grain, Grass, Sxc. timbered as follows, uiz.-Becch, Maple, Hem!ock, White wood, Cherry.
